qas.question: What will a motor do if the load is reduced?
What will a motor do if the load is increased?
How efficient is such a design?
What will a motor do if the load is not reduced?
What will a motor do if the load is decreased?
Where are slip losses not dissipated?
How inefficient is such a design?

context: When used with a load that has a torque curve that increases with speed, the motor will operate at the speed where the torque developed by the motor is equal to the load torque. Reducing the load will cause the motor to <a0_0><b4_0>speed up<b4_0/><a0_0/>, and increasing the load will cause the motor to <a1_0><b5_0>slow down<b5_0/><a1_0/> until the load and motor torque are equal. Operated in this manner, the slip losses are dissipated in the <a2_0><b6_0>secondary resistors<b6_0/><a2_0/> and can be very significant. The speed regulation and net efficiency is also <a3_0><b7_0>very poor<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
